## PLAN YOUR VISIT  

## **OUR LOCATION**

**Museum**  
703 South Second Street  
La Conner, WA 98257  
360-466-4288  
  
**Education & Conservation Annex**  
(not open to the public except for events)  
112 Morris Street  
La Conner, WA 98257  
  
**Mailing Address:**  
Post Office Box 1270  
La Conner, WA 98257  
Approximately 67 miles (1 1/2 hours) north of Seattle, and 142.8 km (2 hours) south of Vancouver, BC  
[ download driving directions ](/uploads/2/5/1/4/25143993/driving_directions.pdf) |  Caryl Fallert-Gentry, "Gaspe Cormorant," 2023, machine quilting and digital design and paint on cotton w/ cotton and bamboo batting. Photo courtesy of the artist. "Birds of Fiber 2025" selection.

## MEMBERSHIP

## Sustaining Membership

​Skip the paper and never forget to renew! With a Sustaining Membership, your monthly support is processed automatically through Anedot, our secure nonprofit fundraising platform. Your membership continues until you choose to cancel. The Museum does not have access to your payment information and cannot modify your subscription.  
​  
**Sustaining Memberships start at $10 a month but can go as high as you’d like—every dollar makes a lasting impact!**  
  
**All Sustaining Memberships include:** ​

  * Two Membership cards
  * Free Guest Passes
  * Unlimited admission to exhibits and openings
  * 10% discount in Museum Gift Shop
  * 10% discount on class registration
  * Complimentary membership to [NARM](https://narmassociation.org/) (North American Reciprocal Museums) giving you free entry to 100's of Museums in the US. 

[ Become a Sustaining Member ](https://secure.anedot.com/pacific-northwest-quilt-fiber-arts-museum/sustainingmem...

11am-4pm  
Wednesday-Sunday 

| 

## We are excited to announce the return of IQFAF in 2026 and thrilled to bring the Festival back to our home community of La Conner, WA. Save the dates and stay tuned for more information soon!   
  
---|---  
  
## ​ _Sea Unseen_  
  
Carla Stehr   
​​  
December 10, 2025-March 22, 2026  
​  
Third Floor Gallery 

Hot Off the Grill by Carla Stehr 

Colorful anemones, nudibranchs crawling on eel grass, and stunning microscopic patterns are part of Carla Stehr's incredibly detailed fiber art. She is a retired marine biologist, and her art is often inspired by features of marine life that may not be easily noticed or can only be seen with a microscope. Her detailed representations range from Pacific Northwest intertidal life to natural surface patterns of diatoms, amphipods, fish, and shark skin based on images she photographed with a scanning electron microscope (SEM) as a scientist.   
​
